function_call.name: get_risks
function_call.arguments: {"risks":[{"Description":"Complex health and ecological challenges may not be adequately addressed through holistic systems-thinking, leading to inefficient interventions.","Impact":"Inefficient interventions may result in ineffective management of contagious diseases and ecological challenges.","Mitigation":"Implementing a comprehensive One Health approach to consider interconnections between human, animal, and environmental health. Encouraging multidisciplinary and cross-sectoral collaborations to tackle complex health and ecological challenges.","Technologies":"Data analytics, geographic information systems (GIS), and remote sensing technologies for spatial analysis and modeling.","People":"Public health professionals, environmental scientists, urban planners, and policy makers.","Owner":"Public health organizations, environmental agencies, and local government authorities."},{"Description":"Competing or incompatible ecosystem services in urban green spaces may lead to suboptimal provision of services to humans and wildlife.","Impact":"Suboptimal provision of services may negatively impact the health of humans and wildlife and increase the risk of disease transmission within urban green spaces.","Mitigation":"Developing a framework for prioritizing ecosystem services and identifying potential synergies and trade-offs. Implementing sustainable management practices to balance the needs of humans and wildlife in urban green spaces.","Technologies":"Environmental modeling and simulation tools, ecological impact assessments, and decision support systems for land use planning.","People":"Urban planners, conservation biologists, public health researchers, and local community members.","Owner":"Community organizations, environmental nonprofits, and local government authorities."},{"Description":"Lack of understanding of interlinkages on the mental health-wildlife-environment interface in urban green spaces may result in inadequate planning and management.","Impact":"Inadequate planning and management may lead to a decline in mental health benefits and wildlife support outcomes in urban green spaces.","Mitigation":"Conducting comprehensive studies to analyze the interlinkages between mental health, wildlife, and environmental factors. Developing a framework for integrating mental health and wildlife considerations into urban green space planning and management.","Technologies":"Social science research methods, ecological monitoring technologies, and community engagement platforms for data collection and analysis.","People":"Psychologists, ecologists, community health workers, and urban green space managers.","Owner":"Local health departments, conservation organizations, and community-based initiatives."}]}
